posts.cooked:
Hi, i’ve been using Signal for multiple years now. I and my contacts keep having notification issues. In particular, messages aren’t recived until the app is opened or messages are recived with a delay ranging from minutes to days. These problems happen at random. Sometimes the delays are short, somtimes they are long, sometimes there isn’t a delay at all. But everytime I or my contacs think that the issue is solved, it randomly happens again. Its not like Signal is unusable because of this, but rather it’s unreliable because you can never know if your (time sensitive) message or call will be recived in time. Basicly, you have to allways keep in mind that signal can just randomly have a stroke und wont reliably work (AGAIN).

BEFORE YOU RECOMEND DISABALYNG BATTERY OPTIMISATION OR SIMULAR TIPS:

Trust me when i say that i have tried all those things that are recomended in this forum and the signal support page. I’m not posting this because i want technical support, but to ask a more general question: How and why do those notification issues keep happening and keep coming back, if messengers like whatsapp just work? Reliable notifications are one of THE MOST IMPORTANT features of a messenger. It seems to me, that this issue is never actually fixed. You can find A LOT of Github issues about this topic that go back for years. Most of them eventualy saying something like “yay it’s working now” only to then come back after some time, to say “never mind it’s broken again…”.

Will this ever get fixed PERMANENTLY AND RELIABLY, or will we just have to deal with it for ever?

Thanks.

Have the same problem on one device where there is gapps and no such issue on one device without it.
App doesn’t want to provide option, what exactly is it doing with the FCM delay info that it is spitting out to logcat?
Is there a pattern as to which brand of phone that your contacts who suffer from this have?

posts.name: Fabian
posts.cooked: Thats also still an issue on iOS

FCM is not reliable. It seems to work for a while after display is turned off and then it doesn’t.

Beta feedback for the upcoming Android 7.28 release Android Beta Feedback
There’s definitely evidence in your log of very delayed FCM messages. When the system doesn’t give us FCM messages, there’s not a ton we can do. I also see evidence of the system telling us there’s no network, even though I’m guessing there probably is. That’s another tactic device’s will use – tell the app there’s no network as a way of controlling battery usage. The most useful thing you can give us in these scenarios is a system bug report. I always warn people though that these can be rela…

Greyson says there is not much to be done when system doesn’t give FCM messages.

I’ve seen FCM delay amounts being reported in adb logcat output. I’ve seen no issues on devices where there is no google stuff at all.

Why can’t app monitor the delays and stop using FCM? Is it better to spend a little more battery energy or should we miss calls? It is an additional irritation that this leads to many call log entries which don’t disappear and need to be manually deleted.

link_counts.title: Beta feedback for the upcoming Android 7.28 release

posts.cooked:
Messages were getting delivered 4 mins after the screen turned off and in the next test it stopped working after just 2 minutes.

Didn’t even get delivered when I unlocked the phone. Toggled data on/off and then I received my test messages.

FcmReceiveService: onMessageReceived() ID Delay: 162124

posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked:
Because it’s not just a little bit more battery and the Play Store has rules in place against this.

If you guys want it solved permanently and don’t care about battery, disable Google Play Services on Android then reinstall Signal. It’ll use their websocket which will never have these issues.

They recently made websocket more efficient though.

posts.name: Fabian
posts.cooked: Any explanation why this is also happening on iOS?

Whatnoww:

Because it’s not just a little bit more battery and the Play Store has rules in place against this.

If you don’t mean because instead of “and” between the two clauses, can you elaborate? What issues other than battery?

Can you point out these rules? Do they also prevent giving an option to the user to override or is just the team’s own bog?

posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked: It’s just the battery thing I mentioned that I would care about. FCM is always going to be more efficient than an open websocket. Like I mentioned you can still forcefully activate it by disabling Play Services while setting Signal up.

A single connection is always going to be better than every app opening one for itself.
Can’t disable play services. Will definitely reinstall without gapps.

At least Signal could do something with the app version released on their website. I’ve had contacts with stock OS also facing this problem and I can’t reach them until they open app on their own.

Whatnoww:

If you guys want it solved permanently and don’t care about battery, disable Google Play Services on Android then reinstall Signal.

That is totally wrong. If you care about your battery you SHOULD install a clean android image without gapps and only use websocket, as the gapps itself use more energy than a single websocket.

(The problem is to find a good rom. I had mixed experiences with my last phones.)

posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked: So you’re recommending people reduce their security by installing an custom Android distribution which likely doesn’t have security patches properly integrated just to make battery equivalent to using Play Services with FCM when using a single websocket?

The security question is a complex topic.

My point was just to correct the myth that the websocket connection does use a lot of energy.

posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked: It literally did for Signal until they made a few changes recently.

It may be even better since the recent changes, but it was quite efficient for years now.

And to keep back on topic: I never had any notification issues using websockets.

Whatnoww:

reduce their security by installing an custom Android distribution which likely doesn’t have security patches properly integrated

It depends. GrapheneOS doesn’t have GPlayServices installed by default and I wouldn’t call it Android with improperly applied security patches.It’s a shame that it’s available for Pixel phones only.

But you’re right, most of the “privacy focused” and “de-googled” custom roms focuses on privacy at the cost of security, often even not delivering promised privacy.

theBoatman:

as the gapps itself use more energy than a single websocket.

Google FCM is multiplexed between all apps using it, as opposed to Signal’s WebSocket only using it for itself.

DirkPitt1:

It’s a shame that it’s available for Pixel phones only.

That’s due to other OEMs having inferior security practices and not supporting security features on third-party OSes, or not supporting installation at all.

QuickBanana:

That’s due to other OEMs having inferior security practices and not supporting security features on third-party OSes, or not supporting installation at all.

Yes, I know it’s not some GOS developers’ unsubstantiated reluctance. Maybe I should say: It’s a shame that most manufacturers doesn’t meet security level required to be supported by GOS.

QuickBanana:

Google FCM is multiplexed between all apps using it, as opposed to Signal’s WebSocket only using it for itself.

That is right, but you need quite some websockets to have a big impact on battery life. I currently have at least 3 websockets beside Signal (3 push connections for emails in k9) and still can go 3 days with one complete charge. (And I guess I could go another day if the backup mechanism in Signal would be more efficient/configurable.) So I assume it doesn’t take that much energy.

fancy_title: Why does Signal keep having notification issues?
